body: Alexandra Chernikova did not want to move her family into a housing project, fearing it would be unclean and unsafe. So after she and her husband separated in 1996, she worked two jobs, hoping to make enough money to stay in their apartment in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn. But she could not afford the rent, and she and her son and daughter moved into
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; Forceful Entry by Police Shatters Peace of Mind

body: Homicide detectives were questioning a Brooklyn woman and her boyfriend yesterday in the death of the woman's 20-month-old daughter, whose body was found in Gravesend Bay shortly after she was reported kidnapped, the police said. The woman, whose name was withheld by the police, reported her child's disappearance to officers around 8:30 A.M.
title: Mother Is Questioned in Death Of Toddler Reported Kidnapped

body: DISTRICT 1 -- Greenpoint, Williamsburg; meetings usually held on second Tuesday of month, but the next meeting is Dec. 1, 7 P.M.; 211 Ainslee Street, corner of Manhattan Avenue, Williamsburg. Board chairman: Vincent V. Abate; District manager: Gerald Esposito; (718) 389-0009. Agenda: To be announced. DISTRICT 2 -- Fort Greene, Downtown Brooklyn,
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE; From Red Hook to Cypress Hills: When and Where the Community Boards Meet

body: ATTRACTIONS Museums and Sites AMERICAN MUSEUM OF THE MOVING IMAGE, 34-12 36th Street, at 35th Avenue, Astoria, Queens. Costumes, set pieces, filming equipment and other items relating to film, television and video are on permanent display. Exhibitions include ''Behind the Screen,'' a permanent display with more than 1,000 artifacts that illustrate
title: SPARE TIMES

body: THE sound of fiddles pierces the silence on Avenue W in Gravesend, Brooklyn, on Wednesday evenings, and Don Coy's amplified Kentucky drawl echoes down the street. In the basement of Our Lady of Grace Roman Catholic Church, at East Fourth Street, Mr. Coy leads about 100 people through the basic square-dance steps: ''Do-si-do, allemande left, ladies
title: MAKING IT WORK; A Country-Eastern Night Out

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE; Bushwick to Bensonhurst, When the Boards Meet

author: Michele Willens, who lives in New York, writes frequently arts and entertainment.
body: TAKING up a whole page in Daily Variety recently was a story about a young six-man Swedish advertising team known as Traktor that had been signed to direct a feature film in the United States. (Albeit a small one by Hollywood standards, a mere $10 million.) The article explained that Traktor's ''idiosyncratic sensibilities'' had been applied to
title: FILM; From Miller Lite To the Making Of Movies Lite?

body: NEW Yorkers have always talked about the weather, but lately their meteorological ruminations seem to be taking on a new kind of urgency. Out in Union Square Park on a recent Monday, vendors in the Greenmarket said they had been arguing a lot about why the weather had been so odd. ''I think it's the pollution, the greenhouse effect,'' said David
title: Just How Wacky Is the Weather?

body: Three adults were under arrest and others were being questioned last night in the deaths of two children and the severe abuse of another in separate incidents in the Bronx and Brooklyn, the police said. In the Bronx, the police arrested a 20-year-old man on charges that he struck and killed his girlfriend's 2-year-old son while baby-sitting the boy
title: Arrests in Separate Cases Of Child Abuse and Death

body: EVERY night, behind millions of closed eyelids, little New York movies flicker, as fleetingly as yesterday's fireworks: images of an Upper West Side apartment where one room opens into another, then another; of verdant midtown oases; of downtown lofts with streets running through them, of an A train that takes the dreamer far from Harlem. The
title: Streets of Dreams; When You're Asleep, New York Becomes Another World

body: In the pulsating sunlight, children churn round and round on a groaning Jolly Caterpillar, while others vigilantly man the guns on the rocket ship, caring not a whit that the paint is faded and the upholstery torn. Their parents watch dreamily, remembering how they once rode the same rides in the same little kiddie land. South Beach Amusement Park
title: For Sale: 16 Rides, and a Fading Outpost of Summers Past

body: Events BROOKLYN ACADEMY OF MUSIC, 30 Lafayette Avenue, Fort Greene. The ''Dance Africa '98 Bazaar,'' a street fair with Dance Africa performances and more than 200 vendors of African food and crafts. Tomorrow from noon to 11 P.M.; Sunday from noon to 7 P.M. Free. Information: (718) 636-4100. BROOKLYN BOTANIC GARDEN, 1000 Washington Avenue. Plant
title: Centennial Weekend; Brooklyn

body: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract. MANHATTAN UPPER EAST SIDE $350,000 301 East 79th Street (Continental Towers) 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 900-sq.-ft. postwar condo; 24-hr. doormen, concierge, balcony, 2 exposures;
title: Residential Sales

body: WITH a fresh breeze blowing off Sheepshead Bay, and the midafternoon sun heating the waterside promenade along Emmons Avenue, the pitchmen were in full cry. ''Fresh fish, we got 'em here,'' one shouted. ''Live crabs, live crabs here,'' a rival answered. Across from Pier 6, George Kartsanis swung into action. ''Get your scalers right here, ladies,
title: The Fresh Catch on New York's Doorstep

body: NORMAN STAHL has a wonderful way with words. He can charm you with an anecdote or impress you with his wit. In his former career as creative director of Ted Bates Worldwide, in charge of such accounts as Prudential, HBO, Pepsi-Cola, Dodge and Colgate Palmolive (remember Madge soaking her clients' hands in dishwashing detergent?), this proved an
title: Weaving Tales From History for TV Series

body: An unemployed Brooklyn man found dead in his ransacked apartment on Wednesday afternoon had been tied up, beaten, asphyxiated and then urinated on by a former roommate and two accomplices who wanted to steal his stereo, the police said yesterday. Tips from neighbors and anonymous callers led to the arrests Friday of the three suspects -- the former
title: 3 Men Accused of Killing Brooklyn Father

body: It was a cold case for more than two decades. The body of a mobster found stuffed in the blood-soaked trunk of a car in Coney Island, the second such discovery by the police in less than a week. Suspicion for both killings focused on organized crime. But yesterday the police said that the man who strangled and then stabbed Anthony Orlando, 41, a
title: School Janitor Is Arrested In '74 Killing of Mobster

body: The tip came from a Manhattan movie theater usher. The detectives quickly put a tail on the culprit, a tall man with a backpack, tracking him to Brooklyn. They surreptitiously watched his house for days. Then, the detectives said, they made a series of undercover buys, building evidence to obtain a search warrant. The man detectives were hunting
title: Stalking the Video Pirates; A Special Squad Moves In on the Movie Counterfeiters

body: Gravesend Using hand-held cameras, Salvatore Stabile turns a bunch of foul-mouthed teen-age lowlifes loose on Brooklyn streets. When Zane (Tony Tucci, left) accidentally blows away a friend with a gun he didn't realize was loaded, he and his panicky friends are faced with getting rid of the body. A neighborhood drug dealer is hired to do the job
title: New Video Releases

body: This week the independently produced movie is enjoying its annual due at the Sundance Film Festival in Park City, Utah. By this time next week, though, home video will have an unusually active independent scene of its own. Dealers would prefer it differently, of course. A big new studio movie or two each week stokes activity around the new-releases
title: HOME VIDEO; From Festivals Or Short Runs
